abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Additional Financing for
            the Sustainable Development of Natural Resources Project
            (SDNRP) for Afghanistan were as follows: outcomes were
            moderately satisfactory, risk to development outcome was
            high, Bank performance was moderately satisfactory, and
            Borrower performance was moderately satisfactory. Some
            lessons learned included: strong regulatory compliance in
            oil, gas, and mining projects alone is not sufficient to
            achieve sustainability. Rather, there is need for inclusive
            growth that is measured by economic, environmental, and
            social performance. A large mining technical assistance
            should have the flexibility to take on broader environmental
            and social responsibilities if parallel activities are
            curtailed, especially in the situation of fragile, conflict
            states where environmental safeguards are not well
            established - as was the case in SDNRP. The extractive
            industries (EI) sector to lead to long-term sustainable
            inclusive growth in Afghanistan, the Bank will need to
            support a variety interventions through a programmatic
            approach which includes, traditional technical assistance to
            the Ministry of Mines and Petroleum (MoMP) (SDNRP one and
            two); a National Resource Corridor Project; finding creative
            tools to leverage financing and mitigate risk for associated
            EI infrastructure; and development policy lending including
            triggers related to the passage of the mining law (2013).
            Environmental and social safeguards must be given strong
            attention in a project providing technical assistance to the
            government to attract new investment. The presence of very
            experienced mining, social, and environmental specialists
            from the Bank, as well as frequent Bank supervision missions
            (every 6 - 10 weeks) proved to be crucial to the project
            responding effectively to meet new needs and challenges
            around the Aynak mineral deposit especially regarding
            environmental and social protection and introducing
            innovative concepts such as mineral resource corridors.
            There is a need for deep capacity-building within the
            project management unit (PMU) of procurement processes,
            procedures, and planning.
